title: 115_s824
content: The Act is known as the Clyde-Hirsch-Sowers RESPECT Act or the Restraining Excessive Seizure of Property through the Exploitation of Civil Asset Forfeiture Tools Act. It includes requirements for the Internal Revenue Service regarding structuring transactions. Section 5317(c)(2) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to specify that property can only be seized by the Internal Revenue Service if it was derived from an illegal source or structured to conceal a violation of criminal law. The Internal Revenue Service must make efforts to notify all owners of seized property within 30 days, providing them with a notice of their rights. The Internal Revenue Service can request a 30-day extension for notice requirements in cases of national security threats. If a person requests a hearing within 30 days of notice, seized property must be returned. The court must hold an adversarial hearing within 30 days of a request to return seized property, unless there is probable cause of a violation involving the property or if the funds were derived from illegal sources. SEC. 139G. INTEREST RECEIVED IN ACTION TO RECOVER PROPERTY SEIZED BY THE INTERNAL REVENUE SERVICE BASED ON STRUCTURING TRANSACTION. The text states that gross income does not include interest received from the Federal Government related to property seized by the IRS due to a violation of a specific law. A new section is added to the tax code regarding this interest, and the amendment applies to interest received after the enactment of the Act.
